title: Cult Australian designer clothing brand to close down within weeks
text:
Cult ﻿ Australian designer clothing brand Sass & Bide has announced it will shut down all its physical and online stores within weeks as it tries to become relevant to younger generations.

The Myer-owned label said it was reinventing the brand and the closure was not goodbye, but a "see you soon".

"From the end of January 2026, our stores and MYER concessions will be closed. From the end of February 2026, our online store will close, too," a statement on the brand's website said.

READ MORE: ﻿ Future of Bondi footbridge on hold after council pushes back decision

Sass & Bide is an Australian women's fashion company. (Facebook)

"While we're offline, we'll be re-imagining what Sass & Bide can and should look like.

"The direction may be new, but a free-spirited and distinctly Australian attitude is at the heart of who we are, and that will never change.

"We know this change may come as a surprise.

"But at Sass & Bide, we've never been ones for following the rules."

Myer Group said the rebrand would keep the label relevant for a new generation as the wider department store goes through a refresh of its own later this year.

"We have spent considerable time listening to our customers hearing from them about the brands they like and those they don't," a spokesperson said.

"This feedback is helping shape our strategy to provide customers with a more elevated product offering across our apparel range."

Myer said Sass & Bide will be relaunched in the coming months.

Customers are unable to return or exchange sale items unless faulty, but are still able to refund full-price items within 14 days.

They are still able to use gift cards until the company stops trading. After that, the gift cards can be traded in for a Myer gift card of the same value.

READ MORE: ﻿ Unwelcome sign nasty interest rate shock is on the way

Sass & Bide stores will shut within weeks. (Dominic Lorrimer)

Sass & Bide was founded by Sarah-Jane Clarke and Heidi Middleton in 1999 and sells women's clothing and accessories across Australia.

The brand has physical stores in all states except Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

Its items are also found in Myer after ﻿the department store purchased a 65 per cent share from under David Jones in 2011.

Myer went on to purchase the remaining 35 per cent of the brand, and Clarke and Middleton left the company in 2014.

The department store will launch 20 new local and international brands by the end of July as part of a broader rebrand keep up with changing demand and trends.

"The launches are just the start, with a strong pipeline of new and renowned brands set to join Myer throughout the year," a Myer Group spokesperson said.

"Each new addition has been carefully selected to complement our existing portfolio and to meet the growing demand for contemporary, high‑quality, and trend‑driven fashion."

title: What the Greenland dispute means for NATO - and the future of Europe
text:
It's winter in the northern hemisphere, and the weather is reflecting the frosty mood between Donald Trump and some of his key allies.

The US president has made it clear he wants the Arctic island of Greenland to come under his control, but he is being rebuffed by both the autonomous territory and Denmark , a NATO ally that still administers it.

NATO nations, including the UK , France and Spain , have stood behind Greenland, with fears the disagreement could lead to the US leaving the crucial alliance.

Greenland is home to just over 56,000 residents, yet it's causing tensions that could upend Europe. (Odd Andersen/AFP/Getty Images)

So will Trump make a decisive move to take over Greenland and what would that look like for the NATO alliance, Europe and beyond?

Why does the US want Greenland?

It's easy to wonder why an icy European island with a population of just 56,000 people is so coveted by the mightiest country on earth, but it holds great strategic importance .

Its location between the US and Europe is key, as it sits in a corridor called the GIUK gap, a maritime passage between Greenland, Iceland and the UK.

READ MORE: ﻿ Iran slams airspace shut as death toll climbs

Greenland's importance is underlined by its abundance of natural resources. (Hannibal Hanschke/Reuters via CNN Newsource)

It links the Arctic to the Atlantic Ocean, making it a vital shipping route when considering Greenland's natural resources.

The island holds large deposits of oil, gas and rare earth minerals, which are hugely important in a geopolitical context as the US faces a battle to stay on top of China .

They are also critical to the world economy, used in the manufacture of electric cars, wind turbines and military equipment.

Will the US leave NATO over the Greenland dispute?

Trump has threatened to pull out of the NATO alliance before, including at the end of 2024, when he cited low defence spending numbers of several allies.

He has not specifically threatened to leave the 77-year alliance during the latest Greenland dispute, dodging the question when asked by reporters in recent days .

"You don't know what I'm going to do," he said in response to questions of whether he would leave NATO.

"I wouldn't be telling you what I'm willing to do - certainly I'm not going to give up options - but it's very important."

President Donald Trump has been coy on whether or not he will seek to remove the US from the NATO alliance. (AP)

Laws drafted in before Trump's second term prohibit him from removing the US from the alliance without approval of a two-thirds Senate super-majority or an act of Congress.

But you also aren't supposed to capture a sitting head of state of another country in the dead of night, and Trump seemed comfortable breaking those rules in Venezuela.

Can NATO survive without the US?

Ask many key European leaders and officials, and they will tell you the US is the bedrock of the NATO alliance.

A key issue is Article 5 in the treaty, which says an attack on one is an attack on all.

With Greenland part of Denmark, and Denmark being a NATO member, this creates a clear problem.

Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen was frank in her view on the matter.

Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen believes NATO will collapse without the US. (AP)

"If the United States chooses to attack another NATO country militarily, then everything stops," Frederiksen told Danish broadcaster TV2 last week.

"That is, including our NATO and thus the security that has been provided since the end of the Second World War."

Trump also seems to think NATO wouldn't last should the US pull out, judging by his comments yesterday.

"I'm the one that saved NATO," he said on Air Force One.

How have Russia and China reacted to the Greenland dispute?

Russia and China are clearly a motivator for Trump's hawkish instincts on Greenland, as he claims matters of national security.

"NATO should be leading the way for us to get it [Greenland]. IF WE DON'T, RUSSIA OR CHINA WILL, AND THAT IS NOT GOING TO HAPPEN!" he wrote on Truth Social this week.

China has an Arctic policy called the Polar Silk Road, launched in 2018, but a spokesperson for the government insisted their goals weren't military.

READ MORE: Trump freezes immigrant visas for 75 countries in latest crackdown

Russian President Vladimir Putin could benefit from the US leaving NATO, or at the very least destabilising it. (AP)

"China's activities in the Arctic are aimed at promoting peace, stability, and sustainable development in the region and are in accordance with international law," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said earlier this week.

On the Russian side, top officials have made cryptic remarks regarding their views on Greenland.

"Trump needs to hurry. According to unverified information, in a few days there could be a sudden referendum, at which the entire 55,000-strong Greenland could vote to join Russia," former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said earlier this week, according to Interfax.

Any turbulence with NATO would no doubt help Russian President Vladimir Putin in his war in Ukraine , with the alliance being a key supporter of the country Putin has been at war with since 2022.

title: Unwelcome sign nasty interest rate shock is on the way
text:
Australia's biggest bank has hiked its fixed home loan rates, in a worrying sign that could forecast an interest rate increase by the Reserve Bank.

Commonwealth Bank yesterday increased owner-occupier rates by up to 0.7 percentage points, to make its lowest fixed loan rate now 5.79 per cent for a two-year term.﻿

Macquarie Bank﻿ also, on the same day, lifted rates by 0.25 per cent across all fixed loan terms, bringing its lowest rate to 5.59 per cent for a one-year term.

Colorful australian dollars laying on wooden table (Getty)

Macquarie previously increased its rates on December 5.﻿

As a result of these changes, NAB now offers the lowest fixed rate out of the major banks, at 5.39 per cent for both one-year and two-year terms.

"The move follows on from hikes from the other majors in December as the fixed rate market continues to factor in the possibility of a higher cash rate," Canstar data insights director Sally Tindall said.

The RBA next meets to determine the cash rate on February 2﻿.

It has held interest rates at 3.6 per cent for several months now, amid worries over stubborn inflation.

Tindall said Canstar expected banks to continue hiking rates ahead of the next meeting.

READ MORE: US seizes sixth sanctioned tanker it says has ties to Venezuela ﻿

Commonwealth Bank has hiked its fixed home loan rates. (Eamon Gallagher)

"The fixed rate tide is on the way out, but there's still a smattering of lenders still offering rates under 5 per cent. How long they'll hold on is a different question," she said.

"Canstar data show there are just 16 lenders offering a rate under 5 per cent - a significant drop from 27 a month ago.

"If this trend continues, as we expect it to, the list of lenders offering fixed rates starting with a '4' could be down to single digits by the time the next RBA meeting comes around."

Rate tracking by Canstar showed a total of 34 lenders had hiked at least one fixed rate in the past month.

﻿The big banks have offered mixed predictions for the cash rate in the new year, but both CBA and NAB have predicted it will again be increased.

Others at the end of last year suggested it would continue to hold steady, but without further cuts.﻿

title: Legacy Aussie retailer lashed over this image: 'Garbage'
text:
L﻿ess than three months ago, industry experts told 9news.com.au the use of generative AI in advertising will be much more common in the future.

Jeanswest has proven them right far sooner than expected.

The fashion retailer, which has gone into administration twice in the last six years, has been called out by consumers for using generative AI extensively in advertising online.

READ MORE: Unwelcome sign nasty interest rate shock is on the way

Many promotional images on the Jeanswest website appear to be AI-generated. (Jeanswest)

Instagram videos show AI models posing in digital versions of Jeanswest styles, and the brand's website ﻿is stacked with AI-generated photos and videos.

9news.com.au has contacted Jeanswest for comment.﻿

A Jeanswest customer support representative confirmed the ﻿content was AI-generated in a statement to the Sydney Morning Herald.

READ MORE: Man wounded in early morning shooting in Sydney

The representative told the SMH that ﻿AI is one of many tools in the brand's creative workflow and said it is dedicated to maintaining authenticity and relatability.

Product photos on the Jeanswest website do not appear to be AI-generated or altered.

Consumers have voiced frustration and disappointment with the brand's heavy use of generative AI on social media, calling it "garbage".

A screenshot from an AI-generated video posted to the official Jeanswest Instagram account. (Instagram/@jeanswest)

One comment on an AI video on the Jeanswest Instagram page called for the people responsible for approving the clip to be fired.﻿

On TikTok, an Australian user called content on the brand's website "AI slop"﻿.

﻿"At the moment, there are a lot of brands trying to use AI and using it in a really clumsy way that's getting a lot of ridicule," consumer psychologist, creative strategist, and Thinkerbell founder Adam Ferrier﻿ previously told 9news.com.au.

But AI can be a powerful marketing tool when used well and Ferrier﻿ said it will become more common in advertising as brands become better at using it.

University of Sydney Business School lecturer and consumer psychologist Dr Christina Anthony said it's likely that consumers will not react as strongly to AI ad campaigns as they become more normalised.

"And ﻿most brands won't abandon generative AI as the efficiencies are too valuable," she previously told 9news.com.au.

Instead, they'll work towards making AI content that feels more authentic and human-centred – so much so that it may become undetectable.

New data has shown that more than half of Australians are unable to tell the difference between a real image and a deepfake .

Though consumers seem to have spotted Jeanswest's clunky AI content without any issue, future generative AI ad campaigns made with rapidly improving technology will likely be harder to identify﻿.

title: Trump family eyeing Gold Coast property as latest investment
text:
Donald Trump's family is eyeing their first Trump-branded property on Australian soil, with the Gold Coast the likely destination.

Conversations are underway to build a Trump Tower on the beach at Surfers Paradise .

The property is located on 3 Trickett Street, and has been a vacant block of land since 2013.

The prime piece of real estate is on the Esplanade, the main drag running alongside the beach.

The site has been in development hell since the Iluka Resort was demolished.

The Trump Organisation is now being run by the president's sons Donald Jr and Eric .

They have been prolific in expanding their portfolio globally.

They have upcoming projects in Saudi Arabia, Oman, Dubai, India, Vietnam, Romania, Qatar and Indonesia.

READ MORE: Donors give hundreds of thousands to Trump heckler

Donald Jr and Eric Trump now run the Trump Organisation. (AP)

It currently has multiple properties in the US as well as Dubai, Indonesia, India, Oman, the Philippines, Qatar, Romania, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Turkey, Uruguay and Vietnam.

The previous plan for a skyscraper on the property. (DBI)

But most of their projects are not owned by the organisation but are simply branding deals - that is, developers pay the Trumps to put their name on the building.

The details of the prospective deal have not been made public.

No development application has been made to Gold Coast Council.

In 2016, a proposal was made to build the third-tallest building in Australia on the site.

The building would have had 479 luxury apartments, a rooftop pool and a series of restaurants.

The residential skyscraper was given approval by council but the $1.2 billion project never eventuated.

Now all that remains is the basement construction work.

The property was sold for a loss in 2019.

When Donald Trump himself was in Australia in 2008 he said he wouldn't invest in the country without a partner.

"If I do something in Australia, I'd want to have a partner in Australia," he told the Australian Financial Review .

But his wealth has exploded since then, especially in his past year as president.

title: Alarm bells over scale of unreported sexual harassment at work
text:
Alarming new findings have shown ﻿that despite recent legal reforms and efforts to change toxic workplace cultures, most people who are sexually harassed at work still do not report it.

Two new studies from Flinders University suggest that it is not just the fear of retaliation that stops people from speaking, but also feeling unsupported by systems that will not protect them.

The lead author of both studies, Dr Annabelle Neall, a senior lecturer in mental health and wellbeing, and director of the Flinders Workplace Wellbeing Lab, says that only about one in five people who experienced harassment went on to report it.

READ MORE: Future of Bondi footbridge on hold after council pushes back decision ﻿

People who are sexually harassed at work often still don't report it. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"The decision not to report wasn't just about external risks like losing a job, it was also deeply tied to internal struggles," Neall said.

"People weigh up whether reporting will make things better or worse and they often concluded it wasn't worth the emotional toll, the risk to their reputation, or the likelihood that nothing would change."

The research identified three key psychological needs that influence reporting: autonomy (feeling in control), competence (feeling capable), and relatedness (feeling respected and supported).

READ MORE: Almost 5 million Aussie social media accounts wiped in a single week ﻿

People say they do not feel supported in reporting harassment. (Getty)

When these needs are undermined - by unclear processes, fear of backlash, or a lack of trust in the system - people are far less likely to speak up.

"Victims and witnesses feel that they're having to choose between protecting themselves and speaking up, and that pressure makes the decision emotionally charged and very difficult," co-author Professor Lydia Woodyatt said.

"If people believe the system won't provide them justice or protect them, they stay silent. That silence isn't about indifference, it's about survival."

Researchers called for more positive and empathetic workplace cultures. (Getty)

Participants described feeling unsure whether their experience "counted" as harassment, fearing career damage, and doubting that reporting would lead to meaningful action.

Many worried about being labelled as troublemakers or weak. Others said the process itself felt punishing, with burdensome steps and little reassurance.

One of the studies, a historical review of workplace sexual harassment reporting and investigation, found these challenges were not new.

While laws and policies have evolved since the 1980s, the research revealed that reporting systems remained largely ineffective.

"For decades, organisations have focused on legal compliance and punitive measures, but these approaches often fail to address the cultural and psychological barriers that keep people silent," Neall said.

Both studies call for a shift towards trauma-informed and transformative justice approaches, which move beyond punishment to address the root causes of harassment and create cultures of respect.

"People told us they didn't want revenge, but rather that they wanted assurance that it wouldn't happen again," Neall said.

"Reporting should feel like a step towards positive change, not a risk to your wellbeing."

title: How much video gaming is too much? Study pinpoints health limit
text:
Video games might not rot your brain - but new evidence suggests they can have a marked effect on your health.

A new study led by Curtin University surveyed 317 students from at Australian universities, with a median age of 20.

The participants were split into three groups classes as "low gamers" (zero to five hours playing video games per week), "moderate gamers" (five to 10 hours)﻿, and "high gamers" (over 10 hours).

READ MORE: Almost 5 million Aussie social media accounts wiped in a single week ﻿

Excessive video gaming has been linked to bad health outcomes. (Getty)

The research team found while low and moderate gamers reported similar health outcomes, results worsened dramatically once gaming exceeded 10 hours a week.

Professor Mario Siervo, from the Curtin School of Population Health, said the findings suggested excessive gaming was the key issue, rather than gaming itself.

"What stood out was students gaming up to 10 hours a week all looked very similar in terms of diet, sleep and body weight," Siervo said.

"The real differences emerged in those gaming more than 10 hours a week, who showed clear divergence from the rest of the sample."

The study found a decline in diet quality once gaming exceeded 10 hours per week, with a greater prevalence of obesity in the high gamers group, compared to the low and moderate gamers.

"Each additional hour of gaming per week was linked to a decline in diet quality, even after accounting for stress, physical activity and other lifestyle factors," Professor Siervo said.

Excessive gaming was also linked to poor sleep habits. (Getty)

All groups reported generally poor sleep quality, but moderate and high gamers scored worse than low gamers, with gaming hours showing a significant link to sleep disruption.

"This study doesn't prove gaming causes these issues, but it shows a clear pattern that excessive gaming may be linked to an increase in health risk factors," Professor Siervo said.

"Our data suggests low and moderate gaming is generally fine, but excessive gaming may crowd out healthy habits such as eating a balanced diet, sleeping properly and staying active.

"Because university habits often follow people into adulthood, healthier routines such as taking breaks from gaming, avoiding playing games late at night and choosing healthier snacks may help improve their overall wellbeing."

title: Holidaygoers trapped in flash floods open up on moment 'tsunami' hit
text:
T﻿wo holidaygoers caught in yesterday's "tsunami" flash flood in Victoria have spoken of the "chaos" that erupted as surging waters rose.

At least one person had to be rescued from a roof yesterday and multiple cars were swept away ﻿in Wye River, Kennett River, Cumberland River and Lorne.

Several waterways burst their banks at the popular Victorian holiday spot following a deluge of 180mm of rain in less than five hours.

READ MORE: Unwelcome sign nasty interest rate shock is on the way ﻿

Darren Schonewille and Matthew Clark were caught in Victoria's flash flood yesterday. (Today)

"It was a pretty crazy sight," holidaygoer Darren Schonewille told Today this morning.

"Just to see how, like, quick the water rose, and the chaos."

He said the flood had come up suddenly.

Cars underwater in the Wye River flood. (9News)

"We were a little bit trapped, I guess, in terms of we were at the front of the and so it was quite hard to get in and help anyone out," fellow holidaygoer Matthew Clark said.

"Seeing those cars float out and then trying to get around those people who lost belongings pretty quickly, it was pretty traumatic for the people.﻿"

The Great Ocean Road remains closed in both directions between Lorne and Skenes Creek due to the flooding and the fear of possible landslides.

Cars were even swept out to sea. (Supplied)

Coach services are taking detours, while drivers are urged to detour using the Princes Highway via Colac.﻿

"Transport Victoria reminds the community of the extreme danger of travelling in the current conditions," Transport Victoria said in a notice.

"Roads may be closed and public transport routes may be cancelled at short notice."

Vic Emergency's latest update, posted at midnight, said the threat of immediate flash flooding had passed.

People were caught by surprise. (Nine)

"Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees are still be present," the update read.

Emergency relief centres have opened at Lorne Stribling Reserve, 45 Otway Street, Lorne; and at Apollo Bay P12 College, Pengilley Avenue, Apollo Bay.

The Bureau of Meteorology has cancelled two severe weather warnings for Victoria, and no new ones are in place.﻿

title: Tourist may never walk again after NYE tragedy at popular Aussie beach
text:
Ioannis Vidiniotis, 28, was swimming with his loved ones at Cottesloe Beach in

Perth

- the city's postcard 1.5km stretch of sand - on New Year's Eve when he struck his head on a sandbank.

title: Perth Glory Women's coach calls for more investment in Australia's 'forgotten' league
text:
Perth Glory Women's coach Stephen Peters has criticised a lack of investment in the women's A-League, which he says has not reaped the benefits of the Matildas' success at the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup.

In recent years, the Glory's women's side has been Perth's saving grace, as the men's team suffered back-to-back wooden-spoon finishes.

Despite this, they consistently draw a small, but dedicated, home crowd of just under 1,000 people, while the Glory men's worst Perth audience this season was just over 5,000.

Speaking to media ahead of Sunday's game against the Central Coast Mariners, Peters said he felt progress had plateaued and money was not going to where it was most needed.

"Our league seems to get forgotten," he said.

"Everyone obviously celebrates the success of the Matildas, which is unbelievable, but is that money being reinvested into the league in the way it should be?

"Are there enough people putting hands in pockets to invest in the sport?

For Stephen Peters, more action needs to be taken. (Supplied: Tom McCarthy)

"I don't know but we've got to catch up."

Peters called for improved governance, better conditions and salaries for players, and the introduction of Video Assistant Referee (VAR) technology.

"We're probably the only league that doesn't have VAR," he said.

"So whatever needs to happen for that to happen, whatever stadiums we need to play at, we need to make that happen."

Players desperate to focus on the game at hand

Most A-League women's players are currently only contracted for just under nine months of the year on a minimum salary of $26,500.

Peters said getting players on 12-month contracts was a top priority to allow them to focus on injury prevention in the off-season, with many currently playing in the second-tier National Premier Leagues (NPL) to make ends meet.

Mischa Anderson (left) reflects on the challenges of being a female athlete. (Supplied: Tom McCarthy)

Glory player Mischa Anderson said most of her team mates juggled second and third jobs outside of their A-League commitments.

"It's quite hard for a lot of us girls to be professional athletes, for example I work two other jobs," the 19-year-old said.

"I think a lot of girls struggle with that. We don't get as much rest, we have to do jobs after we come in here and I think it maybe affects our game some times.

Matildas inspire new generation of boys Kids in regional WA had the opportunity to see their heroes up close at home for the first time when the Matildas took on Panama in Bunbury this weekend.

"But that's the stuff you've got to do."

Swiss-born Glory defender Onyinyechi Zogg said while the A-League still had a way to go, that growth potential was part of what had drawn her here.

Zogg, who has played for clubs around the world, said she was keen to bring her experience to a new landscape.

"I saw [the club] wants to really invest, they want to build something with it," she said.

"It's definitely a good feeling to be part of that growth."

Onyinyechi Zogg (left) believes there is much potential in the league. (Supplied: Tom McCarthy)

Zogg said Australia should look to England, where the women's league was fully professionalised in 2018 and has since enjoyed an uptick in game attendance.

"I really hope with the [AFC Asian Cup] that's coming up that it will give another push and we can accomplish this 12-month contract so that everybody can literally focus on football and the level and everything will increase after that," she said.

"That's definitely our main goal because I think it's really necessary for the next generation as well."

Perth will host the Asian Cup in March.

Report reveals downturn

A report released on Wednesday by Professional Footballers Australia (PFA) echoed the experiences of players like Anderson and Zogg.

It found the women's A-League was losing ground to global leagues and rival domestic sports despite strong international interest in women's football, with a 26 per cent downturn in game attendance for the 2024-25 season compared to the year prior.

Despite the Matildas' popularity, the women's A-League is facing a downturn in crowd attendance, according to the report. (ABC South West WA: Bridget McArthur)

Newly appointed Football Australia chief executive Martin Kugeler said he agreed there was untapped potential in women's sport and that higher investment correlated to better games and bigger audiences.

"We will work with all stakeholders in strengthening and building that in the future," he said.

"There's a new management at the A-Leagues, and I'm really looking forward to engage with the team to think about how we jointly can work together."

Kugeler's deputy, former player Heather Garriock, said moving forward there would be a head of men's football and a head of women's football.

She said it was the first time this had not been a combined role.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Engaged Aussie tennis stars qualify for Open within an hour of each other
text:
Newly-engaged tennis couple Maddison Inglis and Jason Kubler have sealed Australian Open qualification within an hour of each other to read the main draw of the tournament.

Kubler had fought back from a set down against Alexander Blockx before the German retired when the Australian was leading 3-6, 6-3, 1-0.

"I wasn't sure if I would be back," he said.

"I played [the Open] a couple years ago, and it's been a bit of a bumpy ride since then.

"But fortunately for me, today, it worked out, and I get another chance, which is nice."

Jason Kubler was able to watch his fiancée make it into the AO main draw. (AAP: Lukas Coch)

Kubler was able to see Inglis seal a 6-4, 6-4 win over Germany's Tamara Korpatsch and claim her first main draw berth since 2022.

"To see her get over the hump and qualify — it's just so cool," he said.

"I would actually say I felt happier watching her do that than I did at the end of my match."

Inglis and Kubler, who got engaged in December, played at the same time all week — and she initially didn't realise he had won.

"I saw he lost the first set and then he was over to my match not too much longer after, so I was like, 'oh bugger, he must have lost in straight [sets]," Inglis said.

"It was a really special moment.

" It's pretty crazy. It's not every day you both get through qualifying, and are in the main draw of a grand slam. "

In his first main draw since 2024, Kubler's reward is a daunting first-round match-up with world number 29 Francis Tiafoe.

Australian Open 2026: Everything you need to know With the 2026 Australian Open just around the corner here's everything you need to know about the tournament.

Inglis will take on fellow Australian Kimberly Birrell.

Meanwhile, self-described scrapper Dane Sweeny also battled his way into the main draw while fellow local hope Storm Hunter completed a return after serious injury.

It's the first time since 1992 that four Aussies have reached the Australian Open through qualifying.

There are 21 Australians for fans to cheer on this year — 11 men and 10 women — across the two main draws.

AAP

title: US announces 'major sporting event' exemptions from broad visa bans
text:
The Trump administration has identified a host of athletic competitions it classifies as "major sporting events" — aside from soccer's 2026 World Cup and the 2028 Olympic Games — that athletes and coaches will be allowed to travel to the US to take part in, despite a broad visa ban on nearly 40 countries.

In a cable sent to all US embassies and consulates, the State Department said athletes, coaches and support staff for the World Cup, the Olympics and events endorsed or run by a long list of collegiate and professional sporting leagues and associations, would not be subject to the full and partial travel bans that apply to citizens of 39 countries and the Palestinian Authority.

However, the cable made clear that foreign spectators, media and corporate sponsors planning to attend the same events would still be banned unless they qualify for another exemption.

US to suspend immigrant visa processing for 75 countries The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Fiji, Cambodia, Thailand, Somalia and Brazil, from January 21.

"Only a small subset of travellers for the World Cup, Olympics and Paralympics, and other major sporting events will qualify for the exception," it said.

Donald Trump's administration has issued a series of immigration and travel bans as well as other visa restrictions as part of ongoing efforts to tighten US entry standards for foreigners.

At the same time, the administration has been looking to ensure that athletes, coaches and fans are able to attend major sporting events in the US.

Trump's December 16 proclamation banning the issuance of visas to the 39 countries and the Palestinian Authority had carved out an exception for athletes and staff competing in the World Cup, the Olympics and other major sporting events. It delegated a decision on which other sporting events would be covered to Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

Wednesday's cable lists the events that are covered, including "all competitions and qualifying events" for the Olympic Games, Paralympic Games, Pan-American Games, and Para Pan-American Games; events hosted, sanctioned or recognised by a US National Governing Body; all competitions and qualifying events for the Special Olympics; and official events and competitions hosted or endorsed by FIFA, soccer's governing body, or its confederations.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

The exemption also will cover official events and competitions hosted by the International Military Sports Council, the International University Sports Federation and the National Collegiate Athletic Association as well as those hosted or endorsed by US professional sports leagues such as the National Football League, the National Basketball Association and Women's National Basketball Association, Major League Baseball and Little League, National Hockey League, Professional Women's Hockey League, NASCAR, Formula 1, the Professional Golf Association, Ladies Professional Golf Association, LIV Golf, Major League Rugby, Major League Soccer, World Wrestling Entertainment, Ultimate Fighting Championship and All Elite Wrestling.

The cable said other events and leagues could be added to the list.

Of the 39 countries, a full travel ban applies to Afghanistan, Burkina Faso, Chad, the Republic of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Haiti, Iran, Laos, Libya, Mali, Myanmar, Niger, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, South Sudan, Syria, Yemen, and people with Palestinian Authority-issued passports.

A partial ban is in place for citizens of Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Benin, Burundi, Cuba, Dominica, Gabon, Gambia, Ivory Coast, Malawi, Mauritania, Senegal, Tanzania, Tonga, Togo, Venezuela, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

AP

title: Redclaw farmer expands to meet restaurant demand as industry production falls
text:
Freshwater crayfish farmer Nathan Cleasby says he cannot keep up with demand from restaurants all over Australia.

Mr Cleasby, who bought his 20-hectare Townsville farm in 2023, said he was overwhelmed with summer demand for redclaw, despite the industry declining.

"We can't keep up, not even close … the demand is phenomenal," Mr Cleasby said.

He said he aspired to have the biggest redclaw farm in Australia.

Nathan Cleasby is focusing on research before scaling up his farm. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

Mr Cleasby has 5.5 hectares of ponds but said he was working out the next step to increase production.

Working with James Cook University and the CSIRO, he said he was focusing on sustainable feedstock and animal genetics to improve the survival rates of growing redclaw.

"We've got the land, we've got the machinery, it's all ready to go," he said.

"We just want to know what we're doing before we start."

A struggling industry

Redclaw crayfish are native to northern Queensland but a declared noxious aquatic species outside their native range because they out-compete other native yabbie species.

The Queensland Department of Primary Industries' 2023-24 Aquaculture Production Summary found redclaw production recorded by farmers had shrunk by 45.7 per cent from the previous year.

James Cook University aquaculture expert Dean Jerry said redclaw was established as a "cottage" industry with small-scale farmers.

"I think this has discouraged some new entrants to come into the industry, despite the biological potential of the animal itself to be a great product to scale," Professor Jerry said.

He said more long-term research was needed to ensure increasing production would be comparable to other aquaculture industries, such as prawns.

"Quite often, for many new industries, projects are short and sweet, but they don't sort of realise their potential impact because there is no continuation of the research," he said.

Mr Jerry said nutrition and genetics were the areas of interest for redclaw.

"We do know a little bit about the nutrition of redclaw, but there's still a lot of work to be done in that area and the production of the feeds that are cost-effective," he said.

He said demand had remained strong for the product.

Redclaw is increasingly popular in restaurants. (ABC News: Brooke Tindall)

"There is certainly demand for this product and a lot of restaurants when they have the product they will want to put it on their menus," he said.

" It comes down to that scaling issue — having enough of the product being produced to regularly supply restaurants. "

Popular on the menu

Townsville fine dining chef Steele Lee, who features Mr Cleasby's crayfish on his menu, said his customers were impressed with the species.

"You can use the whole animal — the shells, the meat, it's pretty exciting as a chef to be able to do so many different things with one animal," he said.

He said he had seen its popularity in fine-dining restaurants grow over the past few years.

"It's good to see it's growing and getting its place on the menu," he said.

Mr Cleasby said the few producers still in the industry worked strongly together.

"I think the demand is strong enough, the price point is really good, so hopefully we can turn the industry and start increasing production year on year."

title: Are relentless computer updates driving you crazy? You're not alone
text:
You're back from holidays, turning on a laptop for the first time in days, and, before you know it, its little fan is at full speed and everything's running slow before it shuts down again.

Later on, you're under the pump with a critical deadline to hit, and your PC forces an update on you, and then another, and maybe a third for good measure, hitting you with the so-called blue screen of death for a good 10 minutes.

Sound familiar?

This is the modern era of office work, where a bid to become ultra secure with updated operating systems has made corporate-owned computers an unpredictable hotbed of stress.

It seems like the machines are forever interrupting us with updates, often to install new, "shiny" software that — once you've endured its fourth update of the day — is often less user-friendly, less efficient, and somehow makes your job harder.

So what's going on?

A high-level Adelaide-based IT expert, who has spoken on condition of anonymity, says many of the updates we endure are for security reasons.

"The cyber threat now is so high, even to what it was 10 years ago, that a lot of companies are extremely risk-averse and just want to make sure their systems are secure as possible," he said.

Most Australian office workers will be familiar with the so-called blue screen of death. (ABC News: Bang Xiao)

He said corporations used to look over updates rolled out by the big tech they had enterprise agreements with and chose what was relevant to them, ignoring the others.

"But I think what's happening more and more is they're just putting on all the available updates as there's so many threats now, from foreign nationals, governments … someone gets hacked, and it's out in the media in five minutes and can cause a lot of reputational damage," he said.

"It does slow things down."

One corporate manager told the ABC, tongue in cheek, that his job is now "just to sit there and do updates on my computer".

'Shiny' before 'real usability'

Sydney's University of Technology Software Engineering head, Asif Gil, said changes could also be driven by revenue, regulatory compliance, or safety and maintaining a reputation — all of which could impact usability or cause a "misalignment with the business goals and operations".

Less is more, right? So why is keeping things simple so complicated? No inventor strives to make their creations so complex that it confounds users; no one strives to make their lives more difficult. So why is keeping things simple so complicated?

He said there was also focus on new features rather than "real usability" and "people's work habits".

"Sometimes it is about releasing and adopting a shiny tool as soon as possible without detailed problem and need analysis," Professor Gil said.

He said this could be due to an organisation's fear of lagging behind, or wanting a "first-mover competitive advantage".

"But software release frequency needs to align with the business goals and day-to-day operations, including their smooth integration within the existing workflows," Professor Gil said.

Older computers typically struggle to deal with updates and new software. (AAP)

The Adelaide IT expert said large software providers often rebrand their products, prompting people to say, "Hang on. This was so much easier the old way."

"They're just trying to refresh and give you more functionality. The thing is, with more functionality, you need more processing power, and when they do release new versions, in the background, there will be security enhancements," he said.

"Older computers will be more affected by updates, as they are not made for them, and I think a lot of companies hold onto IT equipment for too long.

"At the end of the day, it's a cost, but they don't see the cost in productivity loss."

He said bespoke software made specifically for corporations also had to be updated to reflect external software changes.

Local interfaces were also sometimes updated simply because it was on an employee's performance agreement to do so.

"They achieved it, but is it any better?"

More frequent updates to come

Professor Gil said there needed to be a trade-off between updating software to reflect hardening security regulations and retaining usability and speed.

He said if the updates were driving users crazy, people could expect more of them and even more frequently due to AI-generated code.

Tactics of hold music A professor in music therapy gives her take on the phenomenon of hold music and its ulterior motives.

"Its code generation can happen quickly, but the challenge is, are humans ready to adopt that code, because they are at the forefront of actually using it, taking action, and being accountable," he said.

"I think there's a misalignment between the day-to-day operations and what software can do as well."

In the meantime, just trying to save a draft article of this article to my PC is a minor battle, as I fend off its attempts to save it to the cloud rather than my own laptop — regardless of how many times I opt out or disable the wretched new interface.

Sound familiar?

title: US lawsuit results in mystery cheque from Amazon in woman's mailbox
text:
If you go to your mailbox and find a cheque for US$51 from Amazon Prime, it may not be a scam but the result of a US legal case.

This is exactly what happened to Wollongong resident Laura Wells, who had to find out why the corporate giant sent her money.

"It was bizarre to open up an official-looking cheque from the US, unbeknownst to me that I was even getting it," she said.

The company reached an agreement with US regulators last year to pay $US 2.5 billion ($3.8 billion) in fines and reimbursements to Prime subscribers to settle allegations it deceived its customers to generate subscriptions.

After discovering details of the reimbursement on the internet, Ms Wells said she hoped the full amount would be passed on to her, as banks often take a conversion fee and other payments.

"I am not holding my breath that it will be fee-free but I'm sure I will see a little bit of money deposited into my account," she said.

'Confusing' situation

Melbourne Law School consumer protection expert Jeanie Patterson said the unusual case had caused widespread confusion.

She said the Federal Trade Commission brought an action against Amazon for "confusing interfaces" in 2023.

Amazon Prime is providing refunds to mainly US customers. (Reuters: Gustavo Graf)

"People went on to Amazon US to sign up to buy an item and they were offered two free days of shipping," she said.

"By clicking that button and in fact not opting out, they were [inadvertently] signed up to Amazon Prime, which is about $14 a month — or a year depending on the deal you got — and didn't know they were signed up.

" They then weren't able to unsubscribe and so at the end of last year there was a settlement and part of that was that Amazon had to pay customers that were affected back. "

Customers were offered two days of free shipping, which also inadvertently signed them up to Amazon Prime. (Reuters: Gustavo Graf)

The Federal Trade Commission said on its website that, as a result of the historic settlement, Amazon began sending claim notices to eligible Prime customers in January 2026.

A statement from Amazon in September said the company and its executives worked hard to make it clear and simple for customers to both sign up and cancel their memberships.

"Amazon and our executives have always followed the law and this settlement allows us to move forward and focus on innovating for customers," it said.

Amazon did not admit wrongdoing in the case and has since told the ABC some eligible Australian customers could get a cheque if they "previously signed up to Prime via Amazon.com and not Amazon.com.au".

title: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for WA runner
text:
A West Australian parkrunner has run the equivalent of three marathons, completing 24 parkruns in 24 hours and raising thousands for charity in the process.

Parkrun events are held every Saturday morning in communities around the world, with participants walking or running 5 kilometres.

While generally focused on community building and fitness, Albany's course is known as a challenge, covering a hilly run up the city's landmark Mount Clarence.

The Mount Clarence parkrun contains some steep stretches. (Supplied: Brad Harkup Photography)

Ben Castlehow said before taking on the 120km challenge last weekend, running the course 24 times, the furthest he had run was 85km.

"We went out on the hour every hour — [we] started at 8am in the morning [on Saturday] with the Mount Clarence parkrun," he said.

"And then continued on each hour and then finished up at 8am on Sunday."

Dozens of runners completed various distances during the event, but only one other person completed the full 24 alongside Mr Castlehow.

Runners continued to slog their way around the route each hour through the night. (Supplied: Ben Castlehow)

Running for a purpose

Mr Castlehow used the challenge as an opportunity to raise funds for the charity On My Feet, which helps people experiencing homelessness achieve long-term self-sufficiency.

"About eight years ago I left Albany due to poor decisions of mine, addiction being the main one, and that made me homeless," he said.

" I was introduced to On My Feet while I was in Perth, and they helped me to regain my life back. "

Runners travelled to Albany to be part of the event. (Supplied: Ben Castlehow)

Running has been a part of his life since then.

"Committing that time to myself, it clears my head," he said.

"It just gives those good endorphins that your body needs to sort of calm yourself down."

Marathon effort

Among the runners was 12-year-old Jackson Beeck, who does the Mount Clarence parkrun most Saturdays.

During the weekend, he completed the parkrun course enough times to equal the marathon distance of 42.2km.

"The first half was pretty easy and then it just got worse from there," Jackson said.

"My hips and legs were hurting a bit."

Jackson Beeck (back right) ran the equivalent of a marathon over the event. (Supplied: Ben Castlehow )

It was more than four times his previous longest run.

"I just really wanted to complete a marathon, so I thought I would just keep going and try my best," he said.

Jackson usually plays the likes of Red Hot Chili Peppers and Nirvana while running, but after leaving his headphones at home on Saturday that was not an option.

Running around the place

Runners around Australia have challenged themselves to run 24 parkruns in 24 hours in the past.

And last weekend, a similar event was taking place about 300km away in the state's South West.

Keeton Hardwick completed the 24 parkruns in 24 hours in Bunbury. (Supplied: Keeton Hardwick)

Keeton Hardwick ran a gruelling 24 laps around Big Swamp in Bunbury.

Mr Hardwick said it was a huge challenge that tested him both physically and mentally.

"It's a long way and it's never easy; staying on top of hydration and getting enough calories into you is challenging," he said.

"Physically it gets to a point where everything hurts more and you have to push though.

" [In] the middle of the night I started to get a little impatient — my hardest was lap 23. "

Mr Hardwick took on the challenge to raise money for the Type 1 Diabetes Family Centre in Perth.

title: The 'Sea Shells Teabaggers' swim group helping women find confidence
text:
They call themselves the "Sea Shells Teabaggers" — and with a former world champion at the helm, this ocean swim group has built something much stronger than good technique.

Shelley Taylor-Smith is a retired seven-time World Marathon Swimming Champion and learnt everything she knows in the water at Mettams Pool in Perth's north.

Shelley, 64, has been offering the free swimming lessons for a year. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

Almost six decades since she started swimming, she decided to put her experience competing in some of the world's most challenging open waters to good use.

A year ago, she posted in a social media group, asking people to join her for laps twice a week at her old watering hole.

The group is aimed at mature women, who are finding fitness and friendship. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

"I thought I was just talking to the locals, and I was talking to 30,000 people and that's how it started," Shelley said.

Building confidence

Each woman has her own story about how and why she became a "teabagger".

After decades away from the role, Kathy requalified as a swim teacher. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

Ex-swim teacher Kathy heard Shelley on ABC Radio Perth and wanted to help women gain confidence in the water.

"I got down here and some of the ladies were just terrified and now [they're] just up and back, up and back, it's just incredible," Kathy said.

Loading...

" I haven't taught in over 30 years, and I got so inspired with this group I went and requalified this year. "

Her friend Diane hadn't taken a swimming lesson since high school and would have never swum alone at the beach.

Diane (left) and Kathy (right) find confidence with the group. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

"Just the camaraderie that we have has just made it so much easier to approach the water," Diane said.

Community at its core

There's a seriousness behind the cause.

In 2025, one third of all drowning deaths were adults aged 65 and older, according to Royal Life Saving.

Some of the swimmers are training for the well-known Busselton Jetty Swim. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

But you wouldn't know it from attending the sessions, which involve a bit of swimming and a lot of chatting.

When Hilly joined the group a year ago she needed some help in and out of the water, but she's now smashing a dozen laps of the reef-protected lagoon.

Hilly (centre) is seen as the matriarch of the group. (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

What you can't measure is the pride on her friends' faces as they watch the way she now moves with ease.

"I'm the matriarch of the group, I'm 75 this year and it's one of the best things I've ever done is join this group," Hilly said.

"I've never come across such a random group of women who have all connected and I think we'll be lifelong friends, you just know you get that feeling."

Sharing her medals

Some of the group are attempting the Busselton Jetty swim this year, after previously being afraid of the ocean.

The iconic swim has 3.6 kilometre, 1.6km and 500 metre legs.

Shelley found a box of hundreds of gold medals from her state and national championships and decided to reward the women for their dedication.

Some of Shelley's old medals are finding a new life with the "teabaggers". (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

"I thought it was going to be a bit corny, but I wanted to reward them for getting out of their comfort zones and coming down here," she said.

"I wanted them to really feel empowered, and they deserved a gold medal."

title: 'We don't quit': Aussie returns to Dakar Rally after broken collarbone
text:
Less than 24 hours after sustaining a broken collarbone and sternum that ended his dream of back-to-back Dakar Rally motorbike titles, a defiant Daniel Sanders has refused to be beaten by the sport's most illustrious and demanding race.

The 31-year-old Australian world champion climbed back into the saddle of his factory Bull KTM on Thursday, local time, dipping further into his reserves of courage to complete the 11th stage and finish 13th.

It meant he slipped from first to fourth in the general rankings. A further two gruelling days still lie ahead.

The man from Victoria's Yarra Valley saw his hopes disappear in a calamitous crash 138 kilometres into the second half of Wednesday's marathon stage from Wadi ad Dawasir to Bisha. He careered over one of the huge dunes at high speed.

His commanding six-minute overall lead had gone, but after receiving treatment, he eventually remounted and completed the stage. "We don't quit," he said.

He dropped from first to fourth, 17 minutes and 37 seconds behind the new leader, Monster Energy Honda's American two-time winner Ricky Brabec, who had stopped to assist the fallen Sanders.

While Sanders was left to fight his own personal battle in the Saudi desert on Thursday, Brabec deliberately gave up his lead over Luciano Benavides, Sanders' KTM teammate, while Nasser Al-Attiyah was happy to cruise through another day closer to his sixth car title.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Honda cooked up a strategy for Adrien van Beveren to open the way and let teammate Brabec catch up after the 190km pit stop and pick up time bonuses.

Brabec boosted his overall lead from 56 seconds to nearly four minutes just 25km from the finish. He was also within a minute of the stage lead, but he slowed down so KTM rival Benavides was the new overall leader, but only by 23 seconds.

Brabec got his his wish to start Friday's stage 12 six minutes behind Benavides, so he can eye him. He is counting on his experience of winning the Dakar in 2020 and 2024 to trump Benavides, who has a best placing of fourth last year.

Brabec said: "I've been in this situation before. For the whole two weeks I've been just trying to stay relaxed, stay comfortable and just be confident, so two days more. I'm gonna do the same thing tomorrow that I've been doing every day; ride dirt bikes and have fun."

Tactics played a major part in the day's car racing, too, as Al-Attiyah was content to let Dacia teammate Sébastien Loeb catch up and pass him to have a teammate nearby for any help and to minimise errors on the mazy, dirt track.

The stage was won by Mattias Ekstrom, while Australia's Toby Price, a double Dakar winner ‍on motorcycles, finished in 13th place in his Toyota. He is eighth overall, 56 minutes and 59 seconds behind Al-Attiyah.

AAP

title: Tourist town considers artificial reef to stop popular beaches vanishing
text:
A coastal town in SA's south east is considering options, including artificial reefs, to battle erosion along popular beaches.

The District Council of Robe has been awarded a total of $130,000 in funding to minimise the impact of erosion at Fox and Hoopers beaches.

The town's erosion struggles have been highlighted by recent cliff collapses, and plans to replicate the iconic obelisk, which is likely to be lost to the sea in the coming decades.

The Robe obelisk is at risk of collapse because of erosion. (ABC South East SA: Sam Bradbrook)

Council chief executive Nat Traeger said severe weather last year meant erosion was significantly outpacing expectations.

"With those big storms, we got to where we thought we'd be in the year 2050," she said.

Ms Traeger said the study would look at all adaptation pathways around, including dune planting or even retreat.

"What public and private infrastructure would be at risk?" she said.

"If council just retreated and did nothing, where would that coastline around that Fox Beach area go?"

An artificial reef is being used at CY O'Connor beach in WA to mitigate erosion. (ABC News: Nicholas Martyr)

Team examines all options

University of Melbourne research fellow in coastal processes Andrew Pomeroy, who is acting as a consultant on the project, said the investigation would also look at dune reconstructions, seawalls, and contemporary solutions, including reef enhancements or the artificial reef option.

"Everything's on the table, and then we progressively take things off the table as we look at what we're trying to do, how we're trying to do it and the different levers we can pull," Dr Pomeroy said.

"Whatever we do in any particular location will have much wider implications.

" We don't want to just install a reef at the expense of supplying sand or moving sand movements around. We need to make sure it works in its actual environment. "

Artificial reefs have been installed in other parts of the country impacted by erosion.

Justin Geldard (centre) has been monitoring the effectiveness of artificial reefs. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

In Western Australia, an artificial reef at a dog beach was expanded in 2024, after an initial installation proved effective.

University of WA research associate Justin Geldard said artificial reefs were not the only solution, but could be used alongside beach nourishment and other hard engineering measures.

"It's more attractive to the public because they can see that positive effect that it's having," he said.

"The community at CY O'Connor [Beach] have loved the recreation side.

"It's created a snorkelling and diving habitat and brought a lot of marine species in."

Artificial reefs can be created in a variety of ways, including concrete structures. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

Implementing could be difficult

Coastal engineer Aaron Salyer said artificial reefs broke waves offshore, reducing their impact on the shoreline.

"It's kind of finding this balance between allowing some of the wave energy to come in, but taking out the big sting of it," he said.

"When you create habitat, you create the ecology, and that has potential flow-on effects for eco-tourism and additional fishing."

However, Dr Pomeroy said implementing an artificial reef at Robe could be difficult.

"You have very small, isolated beach environments," he said.

"It becomes quite difficult to implement a reef in that environment relative to larger, very straight coastlines.

Storms last year caused significant damage at Fox Beach. (Supplied: District Council of Robe)

"There may be other solutions that are more economical, but also the complexity of having success compared to dune work or trying to widen the beaches, or changing our instrument management system."

In the meantime, Robe council will use $205,000 in state government funding to install "geo-textile" sandbags at Fox Beach, and $30,000 for sand replenishment.

"They don't wash away like sand nourishment does," Ms Traeger said.

"That's going to be a big contribution towards the protection at Fox Beach."

title: WA farmers grapple with radar outage during wet season
text:
Farmers and pastoralists in Western Australia's north are facing financial losses and safety risks, with a key weather radar expected to be offline for at least three months.

A Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) spokesperson confirmed there was currently no radar coverage in the north-east Kimberley, including areas across Wyndham, Kununurra, Lake Argyle and the lower Ord River, about 3,000 kilometres from Perth.

With numerous pastoral stations and a significant farming sector, weather decisions across the region often hinge on what the Wyndham radar is showing.

Jessica Lingard says the Wyndham radar is expected to be offline for three months. (ABC News: Tabarak Al Jrood)

BOM meteorologist Jessica Lingard said the radar was struck by lightning on Christmas Day.

"That would be an easy fix if the lightning hadn't also caused an internal fire within the radar itself," she said.

"Unfortunately, the fire has caused considerable damage to the radar and it isn't going to be online for a fairly extensive period of time."

A weather radar helps people track and forecast severe weather events and, in the Kimberley's wet season, is critical for farmers.

The Kimberley wet season typically runs from November to April, meaning the radar may not be back until the most critical period has already passed.

Pastoralists and farmers in the Kimberley use the Wyndham radar to track rain and thunderstorms during the wet season. (Supplied: Tim Lanzon)

Farmer Matt Gray said his team at Ceres Farm in Kununurra would typically check the radar at least 10 times a day during this time of year.

"Whether that's [for] planting, spraying, or fertilising," he said.

"Being the wet season, there's very limited opportunities to plant, and making the most of those opportunities by seeing where the storms are coming from and how far away they are plays a critical role in those three things."

He said only time would tell what the financial impact would be on his business.

About 40 kilometres south of Wyndham is Digger's Rest Station, a cattle station that also offers accommodation and experiences such as horse riding and camping.

Alida and Roderick Woodland use the Wyndham radar daily. (Supplied: Alida Woodland)

Alida Woodland, who owns the station with her husband Roderick, said life on their remote property depended greatly on a working radar.

"Just a couple of days ago, we had a really powerful storm come through and we didn't have any sense of it," she said.

"This just hit us really quickly and took out some trees in the paddocks and around the houses, so it would have been nice to have a bit of a heads up with that one."

Ms Woodland added that without the radar, even routine jobs such as spraying weeds were harder, and mistakes — like chemicals being washed away — could be expensive.

"We'll survive, we'll get by fine," she said.

"But it is a huge inconvenience and a bit of a safety issue."

Impacts of outage spread interstate

Waterloo Station in the Northern Territory is about 245km from Wyndham, and sits just inside the coverage area of the radar, close to the WA border.

Station owner and manager Hamish Brett said he "relied heavily" on the radar as it helped him assess whether it was safe to cross flooded rivers on his property.

"It's annoying, to be honest … if you can't see it (the rain), it makes it a bit hard and makes you realise, just how much you rely on decent systems to work during the wet season," he said.

"I think everyone feels a bit let down by BOM. Why don't they have gear available somewhere like Katherine or Kununurra?

"So if one of these radars go down, they can go and fix it straight away."

Damage assessment underway

The BOM said it was assessing the damage caused to the Wyndham radar.

Ms Lingard acknowledged the disruption the outage had on the daily operations of farmers and pastoralists.

"We definitely empathise with those folks who are struggling without it," she said.

Ms Lingard recommended people access surrounding radars, such as Halls Creek, Broome, and Darwin, and to use satellite imagery on the BOM website to track thunderstorms while the radar was offline.

title: Tszyu and Zerafa separated by security in fiery weigh-in clash
text:
The grudge clash between Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa has exploded, with both boxers needing to be separated after a heated exchange at the weigh-in.

The history of bad blood between the Tszyu family and Zerafa is real, and it reached boiling point when the two clashed heads in Brisbane's King George Square.

There is no NRL-style sin-bin at weigh-ins, but two security officials separated the pair as they faced off after making weight, before they came together with a more civilised parting.

Zerafa (34-5, 22KO) explained what had ticked him off ahead of tonight's showdown at Brisbane Entertainment Centre.

"Nikita has put his hands in my face and on my chin too much in the lead-up. I let it happen, but not this time," Zerafa fired.

"It was nothing personal, but it was to show my authority and that I am not a pushover."

Tszyu (11-0, 9KO) said the exchange was a turning point in his campaign.

"We are getting ready to fight. That is nothing compared to what is going to happen tomorrow," he said.

"Once the weigh-in happens, there is a certain switch that flicks in the body, where you are prepared for war.

"I wanted the momentum to change. In the past, in the press conferences, I am a bit more chilled out and relaxed, but the weigh-in is where I really set off."

Zerafa said he was ahead of the intensity curve in a testy barb back at Tszyu.

"His switch might have been flicked now. Mine was flicked 48 hours ago," he replied.

"It's show time."

Nikita Tszyu (pictured) told his opponent Michael Zerafa to "enjoy the pain" when the pair meet in the ring. (Supplied: No Limit Boxing)

Tszyu could not resist one more shot across the bow at his opponent when asked about what his final words to Zerafa would be before the fight.

"Enjoy the pain because I live for this pain," Tszyu said.

"I take comfort in the pain. Pain is where I feel most alive. I know in the past he hasn't enjoyed it as much so … let's love it."

Zerafa had different final words for Tszyu when asked what they might be.

"God bless," he said.

That is not so strange for a man who has a tattoo of Psalms 30:5, which says: "Weeping may endure for a night, but joy comes in the morning."

Why Asofa-Solomona walked away from NRL Former Melbourne enforcer Nelson Asofa-Solomona reveals how he fell out of love with rugby league and turned down lucrative contract offers to pursue a career in boxing.

Zerafa, who hopes to be joyous on Saturday morning, also had one final sledge for Tszyu.

"He starts pretty solid, and he does fade towards the end, so I am expecting the same," Zerafa said.

"I don't care. Whatever he brings, I believe I have answers for.

"He does make a lot of mistakes. I guess we all do, but we have worked in the gym and worked in the camp to capitalise on that."

For Tszyu, who could get a world title shot in the next 12 months if he wins, it is his time to shine against a noted enemy.

"All the history and all the things he has said in the past have all come to this moment," Tsyzu said.

"It is a huge moment for me, and the biggest test of my career, easily. It is the pinnacle of my life to this point. This is everything."

Also on the card is former Melbourne Storm star Nelson Asofa-Solomona, who is making his professional boxing debut.

Solomona will take on former NRL player Jeremy Latimore, who played 182 NRL games for five clubs.

AAP

title: Inside the push to shade 1.3 million feedlot animals
text:
Stretching 7 kilometres, costing $3.3 million and taking three years to complete, the latest project of well-known Queensland cattleman Bryce Camm is all about keeping his cattle cool.

The feedlot owner near Dalby, west of Brisbane, has installed shade cloth across his family's operation to protect about 25,000 cattle from heat stress.

He said the investment was significant, but one he believed paid off through improved animal welfare, better productivity and greater public confidence in the industry.

"Happy cattle are productive cattle," Mr Camm said.

"It's one of those elements in ensuring that the industry's meeting community expectations and looking after our cattle."

Camm Agricultural Group installed 7 kilometres of shade cloth at its feedlot near Dalby as part of an expansion. (Supplied: Camm Agricultural Group)

Mr Camm is among a growing number of feedlot operators voluntarily installing shade.

According to a new report from the Australian Lot Feeders' Association (ALFA), three-quarters of all cattle in feedlots — or 1.3 million head — now have access to shade.

That is up from 56 per cent in 2020.

Lessons from the past

About 46 per cent of the nation's feedlot occupancy is located within 200 kilometres of Dalby, according to Western Downs council. (ABC Rural: Brandon Long)

Feedlots take cattle raised on grass for most of their lives and feed them a grain-based diet for an average of 50 to 120 days.

The industry took off in Australia in the 1950s, helping producers deliver consistent beef during droughts and seasonal changes.

However, it ran into challenges in the early 2000s, when heat-related cattle deaths made headlines.

That sparked years of research into heat stress, and since then, the industry has spent more than $6 million studying shade and encouraging feedlots to install it.

Mr Camm was right in the middle of that push.

Camm Agricultural Group runs a rural land portfolio covering more than 450,000 hectares in northern, central and southern Queensland, turning off about 40,000 cattle a year for an annual turnover of over $70 million. (ABC Rural: Brandon Long)

Back in 2020, when he was president of ALFA, the organisation launched a shade policy that encouraged all Australian feedlots to provide shade by 2026.

While that target has not been met, current ALFA president Grant Garey said the industry was moving in the right direction.

"We'd like to see all cattle with access to shade over time, and we'll continue to work with lot feeders … to install shade where they haven't yet got to do so," Mr Garey said.

Grant Garey says the industry is working to get all lot-fed cattle under shade. (Supplied: Teys)

Mandatory or voluntary?

Not everyone is convinced.

Some feedlot operators argue the costs are too high, or that shade is not always necessary depending on the climate or the breed of cattle.

But research suggests otherwise.

A recent study found that even in temperate regions, shaded cattle regulated their body temperature better and showed improved signs of health.

While there are general state legal requirements for those in charge of livestock to provide sufficient shelter, shade for livestock is not explicitly mandatory.

That gap has sparked petitions, protests — even a lamb being brought into parliament — and the birth of advocacy groups like Animals Need Shade.

A Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry spokesperson said the Australian government had committed $5 million to the renewal of the Australian Animal Welfare Strategy, which would "provide a framework for a national approach to animal welfare and bring key stakeholders together on animal welfare issues of national significance".

The strategy is due out in 2027.

Veterinary professor of animal welfare Andrew Knight said shade should be mandatory for lot-fed cattle.

"It's crazy that in a country as hot, and sometimes as humid as Australia, it's not already a legal requirement that these animals be provided with shade," Professor Knight said.

"The fact that they don't drop dead always if they don't have shade does not mean that they're not suffering.

"This situation is only going to get worse as climate change increases."

Andrew Knight says shade should be mandatory for lot-fed cattle. (Supplied: Griffith University)

Professor Knight said current animal welfare laws were "completely wrong" and outdated but he acknowledged the industry's progress.

"It indicates a genuine commitment to animal welfare when the industry is prepared to do this, and those that hold out against this kind of obvious pro-animal welfare position are not doing themselves or the industry any favours," he said.

Although heat stress may be more severe in feedlots because of the proximity of animals, he said it was also a risk in paddocks lacking tree cover.

Gaining trust

Providing shade is one of several steps the feedlot industry has taken to improve its public image, and the effort appears to be paying off.

Consumer concern about grain-fed cattle has been falling steadily since 2013, with a sharp drop since 2021.

More broadly, trust in the red meat industry reached a record high in 2025.

Mr Garey said a key driver was the perception that cattle producers were ethical and humane.

"A lot of that's been driven by the focus of the industry to do things like installing shade and looking after the cattle and making sure the animal welfare is right in what we do every day," he said.

ALFA estimates about 85 per cent of feedlot cattle will have access to shade by 2029.

title: $3bn wastewater overhaul after debris balls on Sydney beaches
text:
Western Sydney will undergo a $3 billion overhaul of its wastewater infrastructure following an investigation into debris balls that washed up on the city's popular beaches.

Sydney Water's Malabar wastewater treatment system services the entirety of south-western Sydney, including Campbelltown, Fairfield, Glenfield and Liverpool.

The NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) identified the site as the source of debris balls, which appeared on beaches stretching from the eastern suburbs and the northern beaches to the Central Coast between late 2024 and early 2025.

The balls contained mainly fatty acids, a small portion of petroleum hydrocarbons and other materials, including human hair and various fibres, according to the independent environmental regulator.

Workers had to clean up Coogee Beach after debris balls washed ashore. (ABC News: Timothy Ailwood)

Minister for Water Rose Jackson told the ABC the government would invest $3 billion into upgrading the system over the next 10 years, to reduce the volume of wastewater required to be treated and discharged via the Malabar deep ocean outfall.

Ms Jackson said the city's sewerage system was aging and required upgrades right across the network, but the Malabar site had been pushed "up the priority list" following the outcome of the EPA's investigation.

"We've seen debris balls and other issues washing up on beaches; we don't want to see that," she said.

" We want to make sure that our system is fully up to scratch environmentally. "

Minister 'hopeful' of fewer debris balls washing up

The Glenfield and Liverpool wastewater facilities will be upgraded in the first stage of the project.

The balls contained mainly fatty acids, a small portion of petroleum hydrocarbons and other materials. (ABC Central Coast: Sarah Forster)

Sydney Water will also increase its cleaning and inspection of ocean outfall screens, tighten trade-waste controls for high-risk customers, and expand its fats, oils and grease education campaign to reduce "problematic material" from entering the network.

"We understand the seriousness of recent debris ball incidents and the need to ensure our network is equipped for Sydney's growing population," Sydney Water chief executive Darren Cleary said in a statement.

Ms Jackson said she was hopeful to make progress "quite quickly" but said there was no guarantee further debris balls would not appear in the interim.

"As soon as we start taking pressure off Malabar, we're hopeful there will be an improvement," she said.

" The reality is we're playing catch-up a little bit on the environmental side; this is something that hasn't been looked at, hasn't been done for a long time. "

Ms Jackson said limited disruptions were expected amid the project, with the exception of noise from construction works.

"The disruption for services is unlikely; the only impact is going to be for people who live near the current facilities," she said.

"If you live close to them, there might be a little noise; there will be truck movements."

Tyga is a vibey new spot on Carnegie Road.

This bright new spot blends a nostalgia for 1970s Bangkok with modern Melbourne energy. Borneo-born culinary director Esca Khoo (ex-Miss Mi) gets playful with tom yum burrata featuring king prawns, heirloom tomatoes and fluffy doughnuts like the ones you’d find on Yaowarat – the main road of Bangkok’s Chinatown – submerged in punchy, fragrant tom yum sauce. There’s also charcoal-grilled snapper in a turmeric-cider butter sauce and swordfish hinava, a Bornean ceviche. Decks spinning vinyl keep the vibes high.

Must-try: Wood-fired bone marrow topped with crab sambal, served with flaky coconut roti.
