title: Was 2016 the last ‘good’ year? Social media seems to think so
text:
Advertisement

LifestyleLife & relationshipsSocial media Was 2016 the last ‘good’ year? Social media seems to think so Lauren Ironmonger January 16, 2026 — 11:40am Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

Where were you in 2016? I’ll go first. I’d just started uni and I had thick curtain bangs à la twee queen Zooey Deschanel. Beyoncé’s Lemonade was getting some serious air time on my car radio, and Instagram still showed posts in order of when they were posted. I didn’t know what a Labubu was and Rihanna was still making music. It was, put simply, a pretty good year. 2016, clockwise from top left: Kylie Jenner, Selena Gomez, Ariana Grande, then-couple Kendall Jenner and Harry Styles, Karlie Kloss and Taylor Swift, and Bella Hadid. Yes, part of this is just the buoyancy of youth, the feeling of having “the world at my feet”, to quote my year 12 yearbook. But I’m not alone in idealising 2016. The latest social media trend invites users to share photos of themselves from a decade ago, with celebrities like Kylie Jenner, Selena Gomez and Hailey Bieber taking part.

Advertisement

On TikTok, searches for “2016” surged by 452 per cent in the second week of the new year, while compilation videos of “peak Millennial culture” – think moustache tattoos, typewriters and flower crowns, all pictured in sepia tones and set to the tune of indie-folk group The Middle East’s Blood – are trending. So, why 2016? Obviously, 2026 marks a decade on. But it was also a watershed year in many ways. Donald Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton in the US election, the Brexit vote took place and the Paris Agreement came into force (the last of which, a decade later, we’re on track to surpass).

Advertisement

It was a time before AI slop ruled our social media feeds, before a global pandemic turned the world inwards and before Twitter became a vanity project for Elon Musk. Gen Z – the youngest of whom were just four years old in 2016 – are embracing the culture of their Millennial elders, romanticising their youth as a simpler, more optimistic time. Editor's pick Global economy From Gaga to tradwives: Signs of economic doom, according to the internet It makes sense. Millennials came of age in an era of overwhelming hope. Start-up culture was in full swing and it was still possible to survive on a barista wage in a city like Sydney. Fuelled by Obama-era optimism, many felt like real progress was being made when it came to social issues like LGBTQ and reproductive rights, racial justice and body positivity.

Advertisement

Many Gen Z today are understandably pessimistic about the future, faced with a near-impenetrable housing market, growing political polarisation and a dying planet. Many, particularly young women, have given up on love entirely. Obviously, 2016 was far from perfect. The very nature of nostalgia means we see the past through rose-tinted glasses. Clearly, the forces that led to where we are today had been brewing for some time. But in periods of deep economic and political uncertainty, it’s understandable we find comfort in the warm glow of our memories. I, for one, will be riding out the end of the world by reviving the Mannequin Challenge, watching Glee and strumming my ukulele. Make the most of your health, relationships, fitness and nutrition with our Live Well newsletter. Get it in your inbox every Monday.

title: The Australian Open is offering $10 million for one lucky fan. But there’s almost no way to win
text:
In the most ideal world, a punter would pick the favourite for every match and there would be no upsets. If they did, they’d pocket $10 million. But the chances of that happening are, you guessed it, pretty slim. In fact, a zero-upset tournament has never occurred in grand slam history. Last year, 13 seeded players (ranked in the top 32) were knocked out by an unseeded player in the first round of the tournament alone, meaning anyone that only picked match favourites would be wrong 13 times after just the first round. One lucky fan could ride an Alex de Minaur hot streak all the way to $10 million. Credit: Eddie Jim “Even if we use the best possible predictive techniques we have in statistics and machine learning, we can still only get that probability down to one in a billion because there is so much chance, variability, close games, changes in individuals, differences in performance on days,” Humphries said. “No matter how much you know about the game, it’s almost impossible to get 127 decisions correct.” On the other hand, “If you don’t enter, then your chances of winning are precisely zero,” she said. “Even if your chance of winning is one in a billion – that’s still better than zero, even though it’s very close to zero.”

Tennis Australia knows the chances are that slim because it didn’t come up with the idea. It’s actually a favourite of Warren Buffett, who routinely offers huge sums of cash for his employees if they can correctly guess every outcome of the 67 games of “March Madness”, the big annual tournament in men’s and women’s college basketball. No one has ever done it, but luckily for his employees, the consolation prize is a little more than what Tennis Australia is offering, at $US100,000 for the next best guesses. In response to our experts’ number crunching, Tennis Australia director of audience Phil Brook said: “Picking 127 winners is a big challenge, but there’s a huge prize of $10 million if someone has the skill to do it. Last night, against all odds, we saw an amateur beat the world’s best men and women players to win $1 million. So, in tennis, anything’s possible. “In addition to the $10 million grand prize there are two $10,000 prizes that will be won by the best bracket in each of the men’s and women’s main draws. So, it’s definitely worth having a go. Nexo co-founder Antoni Trenchev with US president Donald Trump at the Trump International Golf Links in Aberdeen, Scotland. Credit: Instagram/Nexo “Bracket challenges are huge in the US. During March Madness … everyone fills one out and follows the tournament. Even Barack Obama filled out his bracket while in the White House. In Australia, footy tipping and Melbourne Cup sweeps are a tradition, and we plan to make the AO Bracket Challenge another great Australian tradition.”

Tennis Australia says it is a competition based on skill and not chance. That’s because if it were purely based on chance, TA would have had to pay to register the competition as a trade promotion lottery in several Australian states, and agree to be regulated by state bodies. Loading Either way, the offer of $10 million is a sure bet to get more eyes on the brand partnership between Tennis Australia and Nexo, which professor Alex Russell, from the Experimental Gambling Research Laboratory at CQUniversity, said was handy given those likely to take a chance at winning $10 million may also be the kind to try out cryptocurrency. “It fits in with that whole crypto vibe of you can make a tonne of money real quick,” he claimed. Tennis Australia’s partnership with the company follows a re-emerging trend for sports organisations to pair with crypto platforms. The Open is Nexo’s fourth partnership with a tennis event – and they could certainly afford the $10 million.

title: Carnival Cruises accused by union of 'exploiting’ staff in Aussie waters
text:
Cruise ship workers on boats based in Australia are allegedly earning the equivalent of just a few dollars an hour, with unions revealing that a legal exemption allows foreign-flagged ships to operate under international labour standards rather than Australian workplace laws.

The Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) claims the pay rates apply to crew working on three Carnival Cruise Line ships home-ported in Sydney and Brisbane, which spend much of the year sailing Australian coastal routes with Australian passengers.

Despite operating primarily in Australian waters, the ships are exempt from domestic labour laws under a long-standing ministerial provision in the federal Coastal Trading Act 2012. The exemption was due to expire at the end of 2024, but was extended until December 31, 2026.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The exemption excludes foreign-owned cruise ships over 5000 gross tonnes with more than 100 passengers from Australian licensing obligations. It means they can pay crew in line with international maritime standards rather than the Australian minimum wage, significantly reducing the costs of operating in Australian waters .

MUA national secretary Shane Reside told Yahoo News Australia that whistleblowers had reported crew working long hours over extended periods, with wages paid monthly in US dollars.

When calculated against hours worked, he said some hospitality and housekeeping staff earned the equivalent of around $2.50 an hour.

Carnival Cruise Line has rejected the claims, saying its wages meet or exceed international maritime standards and are supported by additional benefits including accommodation, meals and medical care.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Do you have a story about cruising? Contact newsroomau@yahoonews.com

Carnival Cruises are beloved by Australians. Source: Getty

Have cruise ships in Australia slipped under the radar?

Reside believes the system regulating shipping in Australia "is very lax".

"At the top of the chain you’ve got the captain, first officer and other senior crew — most of them are European — and they get paid very well," he said.

"Right at the bottom, you’ve got housekeepers and back-of-kitchen hospitality staff, and they get paid very poorly.

"Reports we’ve received from whistleblowers on board indicate some crew are working up to 10 or 12 hours a day, often for several months without a single day off."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

According to Reside, some crew are being paid as little as $2.50 an hour when a staff member's end-of-month pay is divided by long hours.

Reside alleges Carnival have "slipped under the radar" and discovered a corner of Australian regulation that allows them to "operate in Australia while paying wages of Thailand or Bali".

"What the companies say is that this is good wages for the economies that people are from, and that kind of illustrates our point perfectly," he said.

"The majority of crew are from some of the poorest economies on earth. Other cruise liners are paying better, while Carnival’s are badly exploited."

Carnival Cruises responds to union accusations

For its part, Carnival said it "has nothing to hide". It branded the MUA's claims "baseless".

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"The Maritime Union of Australia is using Carnival’s crew to launch a membership drive," a spokesperson alleged to Yahoo News.

"Their tactics do a disservice to the thousands upon thousands of dedicated shipboard team members who take pride in their work and in the culture of respect that defines Carnival Cruise Line.

The spokesperson said its teams include crew who have been employed for 30 or even 40 years.

"People who build careers with us, support their families through their work, and in many cases sail alongside spouses, siblings, or relatives," they said.

The union’s preferred outcome is a collective agreement that delivers significantly higher pay, permanent jobs and stronger protections for workers.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Reside argued that if Carnival refused to negotiate, the federal government should step in and remove the company’s exemption under the Coastal Trading Act, a move that would force cruise operators to pay full Australian wages.

Carnival has denied the MUA's claims, labelling them 'baseless'. Source: Getty

MUA calls for permanent jobs, higher wages

Reside believes the Australian public would be "shocked" to hear how low the wages are for Carnival cruise staff.

"Australians love cruising and have fantastic experiences with the crew. When we explain the pay conditions, people are outraged," he said.

"Since the campaign started on social media, we’ve seen an enormous uptake.

"Now people know how bad the conditions are and are asking how they can support the campaign".

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Ultimately, Reside is calling for permanent jobs, saying most crew are currently employed on six-, nine- or 12-month contracts before being sent home unpaid with no job security.

He said that insecurity prevents workers from speaking up, warning that those who do are often sent home and never rehired.

Reside argued that permanent roles with paid leave would immediately lift wages and give workers the security needed to raise concerns, something he said was "critically important".

Do you have a story tip? Email: newsroomau@yahoonews.com.

You can also follow us on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Twitter and YouTube.
